instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Hi,
i have this board, no liquid very clean board. when i press power button, fan spin and nothing more.
When i make smcbypass, fan goes to full speed nothing more.
I check some power informations:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.8v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.38v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.22v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.34v
Do you have some idea?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Do you get VCORE?
Did you resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>?
Check pin 3/<CHIP>U7950</CHIP> for high level.
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL> presence.

You can also try new BIOS file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
I clean me with the medusa, nothing change.
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>=0,920
i resolder <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> in the first time. 
<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL>=3,34V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=3,33V
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>=3,34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message: Cleaning ME doesn't help; try full new BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message: ok but if i try a new bios, i loose the ME, no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Not if you do a backup first.
And Medusa can clean ME from the new BIOS too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Ok i try it, but same problem.
i clean me with the new BIOS.
do you want file?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message: hi, i need your help please. i don't know what can i do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Monitor VCORE from the start.
Do you get 0.92V from the beggining, or note a little drop from initial over 1V?
Test it at L/<RESISTOR>R7510</RESISTOR>.

Try this BIOS.
[url]https://drive.google.com/open?id=1snG09gmpNiHPV43TyfxLEogX29iVVfZt[/url]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
ok good with your file ,the mac work.
but it's not clean me, no? how can i do if my file is corrupt?
i upload my bios [URL="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zZpsTK6Hs5INlgWWomVIEqF1GSXbXhAN/view?usp=sharing"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zZp...ew?usp=sharing[/URL]
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Uploaded file is clean.
You can use it as is, if do not need to change serial number.
If you have Medusa, then change serial, upload to MacBook and fix Fsys checksum onboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message: yes i have medusa but i have the keyboard, can i change the serial without keyboard?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
Use its keyboard, or change the serial with HxD; in your PC, directly on the file downloaded from Internet.
Do NOT forget to fix the checksum!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green led fan but no display no chime
threads.message:
ok problem solved thanks 2informaticos. i fix the checksum by medusa.
the mbp work fine now.
